image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Montana; born in Worcester, Mass., October 1, 1889; attended the public schools of Worcester, Mass., and Washington State College at Pullman; moved to Wilsall, Park County, Mont., in 1910 and engaged in the Forest Service; stockman, farmer, and businessman in Park County, Mont.; served in the State house of representatives 1937-1939; member of the State senate 1941-1945; elected as a Republican to the Seventy-ninth Congress, by special election, June 5, 1945, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of James F. O'Connor; reelected to the four succeeding Congresses and served from June 5, 1945, to January 3, 1955; was not a candidate for renomination in 1954, but was unsuccessful for election to the United States Senate; assistant to the Secretary of Agriculture, Washington, D.C., from January 1955 to September 1955; assistant secretary, Department of the Interior, from October 1955 to July 1956; special representative to Secretary of Agriculture from August 1956 to October 1958; unsuccessful candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor of Montana in 1960; member, Western States Water Council, 1966-1969; was a director of the National Water Resources Association; resided in Wilsall, Mont.; died in Livingston, Mont., September 2, 1973; interment in Mountain View Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1967, 136 pages.
researchRecord.description: An oral history interview of Wesley Abner D'Ewart conducted by Ed Edwin in 1967. The interview was conducted as part of the Eisenhower administration project. Topics discussed include Wesley D'Ewart's experiences as Assistant Secretary of the Interior: water policy and development, national parks, public lands, Indian affairs.

researchRecord.name: 1967, 137 pages.
researchRecord.description: A copy of the oral history interview of Wesley D'Ewart conducted by Columbia University.

researchRecord.name: 1972, 41 pages.
researchRecord.description: Oral history interviews of Wesley d'Ewart conducted by Roy Huffman and Jeffrey J. Safford. In the interviews, Wesley d'Ewart discusses his success as a rancher near Wilsall, Montana, during the drought and depression years, and his service as a Montana legislator, Congressman, and member of the Agriculture and Interior departments during the Eisenhower administration.

researchRecord.name: 1936-1973, 5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Wesley d'Ewart contain campaign materials, speeches and writings, correspondence, and research materials. Series 1 consists of the Wesley A. D'Ewart collection transferred on indefinite loan from the University of Montana. Series 2 contains campaign materials and election returns pertaining to the campaigns of D'Ewart and others (1936-1973). Series 3 consists of papers and materials relating to D'Ewart's nomination (1956) as assistant Secretary of the Interior. Series 4 consists of papers and materials relating to pulic land and water management. Series 5 contains papers and materials relating to Communism and anti-Communism. Series 6 consists of photographs of D'Ewart, his Park County ranch, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Richard Nixon, Barry Goldwater, Montana governor Hugo Aronson, views of Yellowstone National Park, Interior Dept. awards ceremonies, and erosion damage at Grand Coulee Dam. Additional D'Ewart materials which had originally been donated by the congressman to the University of Montana were transferred on indefinite loan for the purpose of consolidation in 1972. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.
